title: "All else equal, our philosophy is you shouldn’t feel compelled to pick a champion because it’s OP."

replies.body:
Having power not be a factor in why you pick a champion is one of our goals. We won't always get it right, but it is something we aim for.

Exactly what 'balanced' should mean is also a tricky topic. Balanced for pro play, such as Worlds, will sometimes be different to balanced for regular play (e.g. champions that strongly reward teams that have played together a lot and are on voice comms). Similarly a champion that's balanced for high tier ranked (which is what we most often focus balance on) may be noticeably stronger at less experienced levels of play (e.g. Garen or Amumu) or too weak (e.g. Azir or Le Blanc).

**Meddler**

Balanced means not having one champion have 10000 overall dmg while the other has 1000 and same other stats, whats so tricky about comparing two numbers

If the goal is to make things that are exactly equal, then yeah, I'm with you that balance is easy. When it comes to hard to compare effects on the other hand, particularly when some are much more powerful in certain circumstances than others, it gets quite a bit more difficult. Comparing the value of Rek'Sai's tremor sense in organized 5s versus Silver solo queue for example gives two really different outcomes. It's a lot more valuable in organized 5s, what does that mean for the overall balance of the character? Heimer's turrets by contrast wreck a lot of players pretty hard in solo queue until a certain skill level, but then fall off massively in effectiveness against a team of skilled players, particularly when that team moves and coordinates well as a group.

Obviously, a champion with a high skill floor and/or high skill ceiling should win more games in higher tiers like Gold, Platinum, etc, all the way up to Worlds level. A champion with a lower skill floor would be best suited for lower tiers, but these champions should generally not have such a high skill floor to compensate.

Regarding the comparisons you made, Garen and Amumu are supposed to be used more at lower tiers of play, but this is not the same as a champion being "OP" in that tier due to that tier not being able to perform counterplay as well. When a champion is picked in higher tiers more, a similar approach also applies: being meant to have a higher level of sophistication and skill put into that champion shouldn't necessarily cause that very champion to be worse in other tiers; they should be able to perform well in all tiers as the higher skill ceiling can be utilized better by better players, who may need this to do better against their high tier opponents. But of course, this skill ceiling should not translate to being OP in higher tiers.

A good example of this COULD have been Ryze. He is a simple burst mage where you can go R>W>Q>E and try to kill someone. However, better players would be able to utilize the more sophisticated parts of his kit, and use other combos that use his full potential better. This does NOT mean that Ryze should have been able to perform the way he did after his rework, when he was OP due to the extremely high skill floor that you added, which was too much and made him OP.

When designing and balancing champions, their kits do not have to have a team element to it (Fiora's new ult, Kindred's ult, things like that). A champion could easily have a full solo-player like kit, but to perform well with the champion, their weaknesses should correlate with how a team works (like an ADC should be immobile or lack defensive CC, and to compensate the support or other members of the team are able to peel with CC or healing).

You have mixed up ”skill cap" with "team utility". Riven doesn't have much team utility, but a very high skill cap. That is why she isn't good in pro games while she absolutely shit stomps solo queue. Same with Fizz.

One of my points was meant to be that team ultility and skill cap should not necessarily be related. A fed Lux can blow up a Zed before he even steps in range to R. In fact, a fed Lux can blow up almost anyone before they come in range for ANY of their abilities because of her insane range and ability to full combo someone and actually kill them. Compared to Zed, who can only assassinate one champion mid to late game, Lux has much more overall impact in a team fight and will have a much higher damage output when ahead. Any laner with kill pressure should be able to capitalize on a lead and eventually abuse any champions on the enemy team that are too far behind to catch up. 
All those "criteria" that you mentioned apply to champions like Lux, Annie, and hell, even Zyra, but you're choosing to ignore their strength and would rather just ignore the very obvious weaknesses of the close ranged, very squishy assassin type champions.

Her utility is almost godlike but it also involves putting your faith in one member to carry you and that's not going to happen at basically any level of soloq. Her damage output will be relatively low, and that's what keeps her from being a snowballing champ, not the fact that she's simply not an assassin.
